mentions.context: ITK-SNAP also provides the option to use some image processing filters like thresholding the image.
ITK-SNAP provides a great variety of tools for segmenting images, both automatically and manually.
Xarticul offers multiple tools like an easy way to delineate and process articulator contours, semi-automatic articulatory measurements and construction of articulatory models [16].
Xarticul can perform acoustic simulations from the area function by using the algorithm proposed in [17] which is based on the Transmission Line Circuit Analog (TLCA) method [18].
We used imageJ software [22] to manually specify the lines and make the angle computations.

Finally, k-wave toolbox has a great number of parameters that can be customised for a simulation, most of them concerning the grid and time sparsity, the properties of the mediums, the sensors, the sources, the number of dimensions (1D/2D/3D), the number of PML, etc.
We then used meshlab [20] to apply Laplacian smoothing filtering with a step of 3 to all the images.
Finally we used Meshlab [20] to smooth every mesh by applying Laplacian smoothing filter with step 3.
Using tools provided by ITK-SNAP, we manually segmented the vocal tract of the mid-sagital slice.
For manual segmentation, ITK-SNAP offers two types of tools.
For the acoustic simulations, we used k-wave toolbox for Matlab [12].
Then, we used the tools provided by the ITK-SNAP software to automatically segment the 3D volume of the vocal tract and afterwards, we manually corrected the result.
For the acoustic simulations, we employ the k-wave Matlab toolbox [12].
We apply this algorithm to our data using the FASST toolbox [10].
As far as automatic segmentation is concerned, ITK-SNAP implements two active contour segmentation algorithms, region competition and geodesic active contours.
For the purposes of our experiments, we used the ITK-SNAP software [11] to segment the volume of the vocal tract.
For the acoustic simulations, we used k-wave toolbox for Matlab [12].
To perform the electrical simulation we used some of the tools provided from the Xarticul software [15].

Vocal tract resonances were evaluated from the 3D acoustic simulation computed with the K-wave Matlab package from the complete 3D VT shape and compared to those of real speech, those provided by simplified 3D VT shapes (near epiglottis), and those provided by either the electric simulation from the mid-sagittal shape, or the 2D K-wave package from a mid-sagittal VT shape.
